hints.content:
1379: 
1380: :::{prf:proof}
1381: **Step 1: Partition function lower bound.**
1382: 
1383: By {prf:ref}`lem-companion-availability-enforcement`, there exists $\ell^* \in \mathcal{A} \setminus \{i\}$ with $d_{\text{alg}}(i, \ell^*) \leq R_{\max}$.
1384: 
1385: Therefore:
1386: 
1387: $$
1388: Z_i = \sum_{\ell \in \mathcal{A} \setminus \{i\}} \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}^2(i,\ell)}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right) \geq \exp\left(-\frac{R_{\max}^2}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right) = \exp\left(-\frac{C_{\text{comp}}^2}{2}\right) =: Z_{\min} > 0
1389: 
1390: $$
1391: 
1392: **Step 2: Tail probability.**
1393: 
1394: For $R > R_{\max}$:
1395: 
1396: $$
1397: \begin{aligned}
1398: \mathbb{P}(d_{\text{alg}}(i,c(i)) > R)
1399: &= \sum_{\ell : d(i,\ell) > R} \frac{\exp(-d^2(i,\ell)/(2\varepsilon_c^2))}{Z_i} \\
1400: &\leq \frac{k \cdot \exp(-R^2/(2\varepsilon_c^2))}{Z_{\min}} \\
1401: &= k \cdot \exp\left(-\frac{R^2 - R_{\max}^2}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right)
1402: \end{aligned}
1403: 
1404: $$

hints.label: lem-softmax-derivative-locality-full
hints.title: Exponential Locality of Softmax Derivatives
hints.content:
1477: :label: lem-softmax-derivative-locality-full
1478: 
1479: For the softmax companion selection with temperature $\varepsilon_c$, all derivatives of the companion probability satisfy:
1480: 
1481: $$
1482: \left|\nabla^\alpha_{x_i} P(c(j) = \ell \mid \mathcal{F}_t)\right| \leq C_{|\alpha|} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{-2|\alpha|} \cdot P(c(j) = \ell \mid \mathcal{F}_t) \cdot \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}^2(j, \ell)}{4\varepsilon_c^2}\right)
1483: 
1484: $$
1485: 
1486: where $C_{|\alpha|} = O(|\alpha|!)$ (Gevrey-1 growth) and the bound is **k-uniform**.
hints.raw_directive:
1474: The previous sections established exponential concentration for the **probabilities** $P(c(i) = \ell)$. We now prove that **derivatives** of these probabilities also decay exponentially.
1475: 
1476: :::{prf:lemma} Exponential Locality of Softmax Derivatives
1477: :label: lem-softmax-derivative-locality-full
1478: 
1479: For the softmax companion selection with temperature $\varepsilon_c$, all derivatives of the companion probability satisfy:
1480: 
1481: $$
1482: \left|\nabla^\alpha_{x_i} P(c(j) = \ell \mid \mathcal{F}_t)\right| \leq C_{|\alpha|} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{-2|\alpha|} \cdot P(c(j) = \ell \mid \mathcal{F}_t) \cdot \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}^2(j, \ell)}{4\varepsilon_c^2}\right)
1483: 
1484: $$
1485: 
1486: where $C_{|\alpha|} = O(|\alpha|!)$ (Gevrey-1 growth) and the bound is **k-uniform**.

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-127
hints.content:
1490: 
1491: :::{prf:proof}
1492: **Step 1: Structure of softmax probability.**
1493: 
1494: $$
1495: P(c(j) = \ell) = \frac{\exp(-d_{\text{alg}}^2(j,\ell)/(2\varepsilon_c^2))}{\sum_{\ell' \in \mathcal{A} \setminus \{j\}} \exp(-d_{\text{alg}}^2(j,\ell')/(2\varepsilon_c^2))} =: \frac{K_j^\ell}{Z_j}
1496: 
1497: $$
1498: 
1499: where $K_j^\ell = \exp(-d_{\text{alg}}^2(j,\ell)/(2\varepsilon_c^2))$ and $Z_j = \sum_{\ell'} K_j^{\ell'}$.
1500: 
1501: **Step 2: First derivative via quotient rule.**
1502: 
1503: $$
1504: \nabla_{x_i} P(c(j) = \ell) = \frac{(\nabla_{x_i} K_j^\ell) \cdot Z_j - K_j^\ell \cdot (\nabla_{x_i} Z_j)}{Z_j^2}
1505: 
1506: $$
1507: 
1508: For the Gaussian kernel:
1509: 
1510: $$
1511: \nabla_{x_i} K_j^\ell = K_j^\ell \cdot \nabla_{x_i} \left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}^2(j,\ell)}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right) = -\frac{K_j^\ell}{\varepsilon_c^2} \cdot d_{\text{alg}}(j,\ell) \cdot \nabla_{x_i} d_{\text{alg}}(j,\ell)
1512: 
1513: $$
1514: 
1515: By {prf:ref}`lem-dalg-derivative-bounds-full`, $\|\nabla_{x_i} d_{\text{alg}}(j,\ell)\| \leq 1$. Therefore:
1516: 
1517: $$
1518: \|\nabla_{x_i} K_j^\ell\| \leq \frac{d_{\text{alg}}(j,\ell)}{\varepsilon_c^2} \cdot K_j^\ell \leq \frac{1}{\varepsilon_c} \cdot K_j^\ell
1519: 
1520: $$
1521: 
1522: (using $d_{\text{alg}}/\varepsilon_c \ll 1$ for effective contributors).
1523: 
1524: **Step 3: Partition function derivative.**
1525: 
1526: $$
1527: \nabla_{x_i} Z_j = \sum_{\ell' \neq j} \nabla_{x_i} K_j^{\ell'} = -\frac{1}{\varepsilon_c^2} \sum_{\ell'} K_j^{\ell'} \cdot d_{\text{alg}}(j,\ell') \cdot \nabla_{x_i} d_{\text{alg}}(j,\ell')
1528: 
1529: $$
1530: 
1531: **Key observation**: If $i = j$ or $i = \ell$, the derivative acts directly on the exponential. If $i \neq j, \ell$, the derivative couples through the N-body softmax structure. However, by exponential concentration:
1532: 
1533: $$
1534: \|\nabla_{x_i} Z_j\| \leq \frac{k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}}{\varepsilon_c^2} \cdot Z_j \leq \frac{C_{\text{eff}}}{\varepsilon_c^2} \cdot Z_j
1535: 
1536: $$
1537: 
1538: where $k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} = O(\rho_{\max} \varepsilon_c^{2d} (\log k)^d)$ grows logarithmically with $k$.
1539: 
1540: **Step 4: Assemble first derivative bound.**
1541: 
1542: $$
1543: |\nabla_{x_i} P(c(j) = \ell)| \leq \frac{|\nabla K_j^\ell| \cdot Z_j + K_j^\ell \cdot |\nabla Z_j|}{Z_j^2} \leq \frac{C_1}{\varepsilon_c^2} \cdot P(c(j) = \ell)
1544: 
1545: $$
1546: 
1547: where $C_1 = O(1 + k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)})$ contains the $(\log k)^d$ factor, which is **absorbed into higher-order Gevrey-1 constants** (see §7.1 for how derivative locality prevents this from affecting k-uniformity).
1548: 
1549: **Step 5: Higher derivatives by induction.**
1550: 
1551: For $|\alpha| \geq 2$, apply Faà di Bruno formula to $\nabla^\alpha \log P = \nabla^\alpha (\log K_j^\ell - \log Z_j)$. Each term has structure:
1552: 
1553: $$
1554: \nabla^\alpha K_j^\ell = K_j^\ell \cdot \text{(polynomial of degree } |\alpha| \text{ in } d_{\text{alg}}, \nabla d_{\text{alg}}, \ldots)
1555: 
1556: $$
1557: 
1558: By {prf:ref}`lem-dalg-derivative-bounds-full`, $\|\nabla^m d_{\text{alg}}\| \leq C_m \varepsilon_d^{1-m}$. For $\varepsilon_d \ll \varepsilon_c$ (typical), the dominant factor is $\varepsilon_c^{-2|\alpha|}$ from repeated differentiation of the exponential.
1559: 
1560: Exponential decay: The softmax structure ensures that walkers with $d_{\text{alg}}(j,\ell) > R_{\text{eff}}$ contribute $\exp(-R_{\text{eff}}^2/(2\varepsilon_c^2))$ to probabilities and $\exp(-R_{\text{eff}}^2/(4\varepsilon_c^2))$ to derivatives (from quotient rule cancellations). This provides the claimed **double exponential suppression** for distant walkers.
